awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A Scalable Cloud-based Route Optimization Software for Efficient Aerial and Road Logistics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a software application to generate optimized route plans for parcel delivery.  The goal is to empower last-mile service providers who employ electric trucks and a mixed truck-drone fleet. The adoption of electric trucks and autonomous drones for last-mile logistics has risen steadily in the United States due to growing parcel volumes, rising costs, changing customer expectations, and increasing corporate climate pledges. Lack of capabilities in the existing technology limits the safe, seamless and efficient use of such emerging ground and aerial vehicles. The proposed software application may meet the emerging market needs by enabling logistic managers, route planners, dispatchers, and truck drivers with faster planning, greater visibility, real-time tracking and turn-by-turn navigation. This may allow service providers to lower supply chain costs and be competitive while facilitating last-mile delivery solutions that lead to lower carbon emissions and faster fulfillment. These capabilities may accelerate the adoption of electric trucks and drones for package delivery and alleviate the growing strain on this distribution system.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a cloud-based route optimization software that will generate last-mile distribution plans for electric trucks and hybrid truck-drone systems.  The proposed machine learning and optimization-based decomposition algorithms are designed to exploit problem-specific characteristics, such as battery constraints, charging operations, and payload capacity, to efficiently solve complex routing problems. The algorithm also may account for real-life spatial (e.g., no-fly zones), temporal (e.g., time-of-day operating restrictions) and logistical (e.g., customer availability) constraints to ensure practical route plans. In addition, the proposed technology also may allow an active traffic management strategy by generating an alternative route plan in real-time using a deep reinforcement learning-based dynamic rerouting model. The proposed route optimization software may lead to new theories and contribute to the state-of-the-art knowledge on route planning methods and advance the capabilities of route optimization software to handle new logistics technologies for efficient ground and aerial last-mile delivery service.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
I-Corps: A Scalable Cloud-based Route Optimization Software for Efficient Aerial and Road Logistics

Award ID: TIP- 2240977

Outcome Report

 

This project provides a comprehensive understanding of the technical challenges and unmet needs of different customer segments in last-mile logistics. The team conducted more than 150 customer discovery interviews to understand the value proposition, trends and regulations pertaining to last-mile delivery planning, especially the software requirements that are vital for route management of emerging technologies such as electric trucks, drones or a combined truck-drone delivery system. The team interviewed different stakeholders, such as supply chain/logistics managers, truck drivers, fleet managers, independent delivery contractors, drone operators, and founders/CEOs/executives of logistics companies in various sectors, including healthcare delivery, package delivery, retail delivery, and humanitarian logistics. The main findings from the customer discovery interviews are as follows:

1. Driver shortage and retention are common challenges among all last-mile service providers. The exponential growth of e-commerce, coupled with a shift in people’s purchasing behavior for online shopping, has strained existing delivery systems, leading to driver turnover and overuse. This challenge is not unique to the U.S., and customers worldwide were experiencing a similar issue.


2. The capabilities of several existing route planning platforms did not fully meet the customer’s expectations regarding real-time routing, communication and management of truck fleets. The team learned that, on many occasions, manual intervention and route adjustments were required from logistics planners, leading to delays, longer routes, and increased costs.


3. Although electric trucks are gaining popularity for last-mile services, current technologies for route planning are not well suited to generate reliable or cost-optimal routes for electric trucks. The team found that the stakeholders are unable to leverage their existing route management software to account for the unique characteristics of a mixed fleet of traditional gas-powered trucks and electric trucks.  


4. The use of drones for the delivery of lightweight packages has the potential to optimize last-mile operations. The healthcare sector has been at the forefront of adopting drone technology. Drones’ ability to deliver medical packages swiftly to geographically remote areas has led the healthcare sector to operate drones widely. Currently, drones deliver specimens, vaccines, and other vital medical supplies in Africa, Canada, and the U.S. However, to facilitate large-scale operations, it is necessary to establish route plans that are safe and reliable. In other words, the highest priority for the stakeholders is to generate safe routes, followed by optimization of delivery cost and time.


5  A combined truck-drone delivery system is a viable alternative for many last-mile providers who serve a wide geographic region and deliver packages of different sizes/weights.  Several companies are exploring the use of a truck-drone delivery system, and some of the stakeholders whom the team interviewed have already piloted numerous truck-drone tandem delivery operations. Currently, there is no route management platform to generate safe and efficient delivery plans for a truck-drone system. Such a software platform is needed for successful piloting and enabling scalable operations.

The main outcomes of the project include a provisional patent on a route management system for an electric truck and a drone delivery system. Additionally, the project team was awarded an NSF PFI-TT grant to develop and pilot a route management platform that optimizes delivery plans for electric trucks and drones while addressing the limitations of existing technologies.

The broader impacts of this project are (1) identification of market potential, technical barriers/knowledge gaps, and societal benefits of last-mile delivery using electric trucks and drones, (2) training of a graduate student on customer discovery and becoming an independent entrepreneur.  The insights gained from the customer discovery process will enable the team to develop technology that addresses the market and societal needs in last-mile logistics services. This advancement will help service providers reduce supply chain costs, enhance competitiveness, decrease carbon emissions, and expedite order fulfillment. Importantly, the technology under development holds the potential to transform the last-mile delivery market, thereby bolstering the nation’s economic prosperity and overall welfare.

 


Last Modified: 05/22/2024
Modified by: Sharan Srinivas
